Graphical abstract Sea urchin-like Co-Mo bimetallic nitride was synthesized via one-step method, which can enhance the polysulfide redox conversion through the adsorption-catalysis synergistic effect. Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries are considered as one of the most promising next generation energy storage systems due to the high theoretical specific capacity, low cost, and environmental benignity. However, the notorious shuttle effect of polysulfides hinders the practical application of Li-S batteries. Herein, we have rationally designed and synthesized sea urchin-like Co-Mo bimetallic nitride (Co3Mo3N) in the absence of additional nitrogen sources with only one step, which was applied as the sulfur host materials for Li-S batteries. The results indicate that Co3Mo3N can efficiently anchor and catalyze the conversion of polysulfides, thus accelerating the electrochemical reaction kinetics and enabling prominent electrochemical properties. As a consequence, the S@Co3Mo3N cathode exhibits a high rate performance of 705 mAh g−1 at 3 C rate and an excellent cycling stability with a low capacity fading rate of 0.08% per cycle at 1 C over 600 cycles. Even at a high sulfur loading of 5.4 cmg cm−2, it delivers a high initial areal capacity of 4.50 mAh cm−2, which is still retained at 3.64 mAh cm−2 after 120 cycles. Furthermore, the catalytic mechanism and structural stability of Co3Mo3N during cycling were elucidated by a combination of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and X-ray absorption fine structure. This work highlights the strategy of structure-catalysis engineering of bimetallic nitride, which is expected to have a wide application in Li-S batteries. Keywords Lithium-sulfur batteries Co3Mo3N Shuttle effect Catalytic effect XAFS 1. Introduction In order to alleviate the shortage of energy, it is imperative to find an energy storage system with high energy density. Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries, because of the high theoretical specific capacity (1675 mAh g−1) and energy density (2600 kWh kg−1), low cost, and environmental friendliness, have attracted widespread attention, which are considered as one of the promising candidates for next-generation energy storage systems [1,2]. Unfortunately, there are still many challenges hindering the practical application of Li-S batteries. First of all, both sulfur (5 × 10−30 S cm−1) and discharge products Li2S2/Li2S (3 × 10−7 S cm−1) have ultra-low conductivity, which severely hinder the electron transfer and ion migration during the electrochemical reaction process, leading to high electrochemical polarization and low sulfur utilization [3–6]. Secondly, the huge volumetric strain during the charge–discharge process results in the mechanical degradation of the active materials. Thirdly, the severe shuttle effect causes the capacity loss and reduces the coulombic efficiency of Li-S batteries. To address these issues, many forward-looking and practical research programs have been proposed and great progress has been achieved, such as introducing conductive materials (e.g., single-wall/multi-wall carbon nanotubes [7,8], nanofibers [9], and graphene [10] or constructing yolk-shell hollow structure [11,12] to promote the electron transport and ion migration, and building physical/chemical bonds between the sulfur host materials and polysulfides to effectively suppress the shuttle effect. With the deepening of research on Li-S batteries, it has been found that the accumulation of a large amount of polysulfides will increase the viscosity of the electrolyte and decrease the reaction rate [13]. Recently, it has been realized that applying various catalytic host materials to Li-S batteries can greatly improve the electrochemical kinetics of polysulfide redox reactions. For example, Arava et al. demonstrated for the first time that Pt can be used as a good catalyst to accelerate the conversion of polysulfides [14]. Subsequently, a series of metals and bimetals, including Ni [15], Au [16], Co [17], Fe [18], Pd [19], Co x Sn y [20], Pd3Co [21], and Co7Fe3 [22], have been explored as the electrocatalysts for the conversion of polysulfides. In contrast, polar bimetallic compounds have abundant empty d-orbitals and active sites, which are expected to form strong chemical bonds with the electron-rich polysulfides and more efficiently promote the polysulfide conversion [23,24]. In principle, besides the catalytic properties, the ideal sulfur host material should also have high electron and ion transport. Therefore, combining the advantages of polar bimetallic compounds and polar atoms doped carbon materials is a promising strategy. Notably, hybrids composed of conductive carbon and bimetallic materials, especially metal–organic frameworks derivatives (MOFs-derivatives), e.g., oxides [25,26], sulfides [27,28], and carbides [29,30], have been reported as additives or host materials for Li-S batteries. In contrast, bimetallic nitrides, which possess the properties of unique electronic structure, high electrical conductivity, excellent chemical stability and prominent electrocatalytic activity [14,31,32], have been less explored in Li-S batteries. Bimetallic nitrides are a kind of transition metal interstitial compound that usually exist in the sub-stoichiometric phase with a large number of vacancies, which provide more active sites for catalytic processes [33]. As a consequence of the synergistic effect of the two metals, the activity and stability of the bimetallic nitrides can be significantly improved compared with the corresponding monometallic nitrides [34]. However, the reported bimetallic nitrides are usually fabricated via nitridation of metal-based precursors in nitrogen-rich atmosphere, e.g., ammonia gas [35], dicyanamide [36], urea [37], and even nitrogen [38], which are usually complicated and impractical for the practical applications. Therefore, it is of great significance to develop a new strategy to prepare bimetallic nitride without additional nitrogen source. Herein, we report the preparation of sea urchin-like Co-Mo bimetallic nitride (Co3Mo3N) without additional nitrogen source as the sulfur host materials for Li-S batteries for the first time. Because of the outstanding electrocatalytic properties of Co3Mo3N towards polysulfide redox conversion, the Li-S batteries with S@Co3Mo3N cathodes demonstrate a high initial discharge capacity of 1041.1 mAh g−1 at 0.5 C, a good long-term cycling stability with a capacity attenuation of 0.08% per cycle after 600 cycles at 1 C, and a superior rate capacity of 704.7 mAh g−1 at 3 C. With increasing the sulfur loading to 5.4 mg cm−2, the areal capacity still reaches to 4.5 mAh cm−2, which is retained at 3.64 mAh cm−2 after 120 cycles at 0.1 C. 2 Experimental 2.1 Fabrication of the S@MOFs-derivatives cathodes 2.1.1 Synthesis of precursors For the preparation of Mo-doped ZIF-67, Co(NO3)2·6H2O (2.91 g, 10 mmol) and 2-methylimidazole (2-MeIm; 6.568 g, 80 mmol) were dissolved in 200 mL methanol to form solution A and solution B, respectively. After stirring vigorously for 10 minutes, Phosphomolybdic acid hydrate (PMA, 0.152 g, 0.083 mmol) was added to solution A and stirred for another half hour until PMA was completely dissolved. Then solution B was rapidly poured into solution A and stirred vigorously for 24 h at room temperature. Then the light purple Mo-doped ZIF-67 products were collected, centrifuged and washed with ethanol several times, and then dried in vacuum at 60 °C. For the preparation of ZIF-67, the synthetic route was basically identical to the synthesis of Mo-doped ZIF-67, except without adding PMA into the above solution A. 2.1.2 MOFs-derived metal matrix composites For the preparation of Co3Mo3N, the as-prepared samples of Mo-doped ZIF-67 precursor was placed in corundum porcelain boat and then transferred into a temperature-program tube furnace under H2/Ar atmosphere. Firstly, the temperature was risen to 550 °C at a heating ramp of 5 °C min−1 and held for 2 h. Secondly, the pyrolysis temperature reached to 800 °C at a heating ramp of 2 °C min−1 and maintained for 3 h. After that, the sample was cooled to room temperature then the black powder was collected. For the preparation of Co/Mo-N-C, the as-prepared sample of ZIF-67 precursor was physically mixed with PMA, and the subsequent heat treatment process was the same as the preparation of Co3Mo3N. The Co-N-C was prepared by the same process. 2.1.3 Preparation of S@MOFs-derivatives cathodes The sulfur was infiltrated into MOFs-derivatives materials by melting method. Co3Mo3N and sublimated sulfur were weighed in a mass ratio of 1:3 and grounded for 15 min in a mortar, and then placed on aluminum foil into reaction kettle at 155 °C for 15 h. After cooling to room temperature naturally, the products of S@MOFs-derivatives were collected. The S@Co3Mo3N, Super P, and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) were dispersed in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) with a mass ratio 7:2:1 to form the slurry. And then the slurry was coated on the carbon-coated Al foil by the scraper coating method. Same procedure was applied for the preparation of S@Co-N-C and S@Co/Mo-N-C cathodes. The average areal loading of S@MOFs-derivatives cathodes are between 1.0 and 5.4 mg cm−2. 2.2 Characterization of materials The phase of the samples was identified by the X-ray diffraction (XRD, Bruker D8) equipped with graphite-monochromatized Cu Kα radiation. The morphology and microstructure of the samples were performed by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, ZEISS G500) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, TALOS 200X). The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, ULTRA DLD) was used for detecting the compositions and chemical states of on the surface of materials. The adsorption degree of lithium polysulfide was investigated by UV–visible absorption spectrometer (UV–vis, PE 950). The sulfur content can be obtained by Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). The pore diameter distribution and specific surface area of the samples was measured by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET, ASAP2050). The vibrational and rotational information of the molecules was tested by Raman spectrometer (Raman, HR 800). Metallic element content was tested by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES, M90). The XAFS experiments were performed at the beamline 1W1B in Beijing Synchrotron Radiation Facility (BSRF) and beamline 11B of Shanghai Synchrotron Radiation Facility (SSRF). For ex-situ characterizations (mainly XPS and XAFS), standard procedures were used to handle samples, including the disassembly, rinse, and transfer. The electrodes at different states of charge were disassembled and rinsed with DME solution thoroughly to remove the surface residue. Then a home-made suitcase was used to directly transfer the samples from glovebox to sample loading chamber without the exposure to air to avoid the change of charge states of cycled electrodes. 2.3 Electrochemical measurements Standard 2025 coin cells were assembled in the glove box filling with Argon gas. The electrolyte consists of 1 mol L−1 Lithium bis(trifluoromethan-esul-phonyl)imide (LiTFSI) and 2% LiNO3 was added to a solvent of 1,2-dimethoxyethane (DME) and 1,3-dioxolane (DOL) (1:1, v/v). The S@Co3Mo3N, S@Co-N-C, S@Co/Mo-N-C cathodes were used to assemble the Li-S batteries with lithium metal as anode. It should be noted that each battery component, including the amount of electrolyte and lithium anode, has an important impact on the electrochemical performance and actual energy density of batteries [39]. Here the mass loading of the sulfur electrodes is 1.0–1.2 mg cm−2 with a thickness of 25–30 μm. The area of sulfur cathode and lithium anode is 1.13 and 1.91 cm2, respectively. The thickness of lithium anode is 0.45 mm, and the electrolyte volume in each cell is 30 μL. While under high sulfur loading condition, the E/S ratio is 15 μL mg−1. The galvanostatic charge/discharge test was performed in the voltage range of 1.7–2.8 V (vs. Li/Li+) by LAND 2001 system. Cycle voltammetry (CV) was carried out LAND workstation at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1, and the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy was recorded in the frequency ranging from 10 Hz to 100 kHz. To study the catalytic effect of the bimetallic nitride on the electrochemical kinetics, symmetric cells were assembled using various samples as the work and the counter electrode. The areal loading of the electrode was about 1 mg cm−2, and the electrolyte is 0.2 mol L−1 Li2S6 solution. CV curves were measured in the potential ranging from −1 to 1 V (vs. Li/Li+) at a scan rate of 0.8 mV s−1. 2.4 Polysulfide adsorption experiments Lithium polysulfide (Li2S6) solution (0.5 mol L−1) was prepared by adding the stoichiometric S and Lithium sulfide (Li2S) with a mass ratio 5:1 into DME/DOL (1:1, v/v) solvent and then it was stirred vigorously at 60 °C for 24 h. Then Li2S6 solution was diluted to 2 mmol L−1 for the adsorption experiments. Typically, 10 mg of as-prepared samples were separately placed in Li2S6 solution. The powder was recovered from Li2S6 solution after full adsorption and dried for XPS analysis. All the products were performed in angon-filled glovebox. 3 Results and discussion The schematic illustration of the preparation of urchin-like Co3Mo3N is shown in Fig. 1 (a). The precursor Mo-doped ZIF-67 was synthesized by the reaction of Co2+ and PMA coordinated with 2-methylimidazole. Fig. S1 exhibits the morphology of Mo-doped ZIF-67 and ZIF-67 precursors, where ZIF-67 is polyhedral and Mo-doped ZIF-67 is spherical. Co3Mo3N was prepared by high-temperature calcination of the precursor under H2/Ar atmosphere. As displayed in Fig. 1(b and c), the SEM and TEM images of Co3Mo3N show a uniform sea urchin-like structure with an average diameter of 200 nm, which is surrounded by carbon nanotubes (CNTs) with Co nanoparticles embedded on top (inset of Fig. 1c and Fig. S3). Furthermore, the lattice fringe of the high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), the clear lattice fringes with interplanar spacing of 0.212, 0.205 and 0.36 nm correspond to the (511) plane of cubic Co3Mo3N, the (111) plane of Co, and the (002) plane of carbon, respectively [40]. The corresponding high-angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscope (HAADF-STEM) image (Fig. 1e) and elemental mappings (Fig. 1f–i) indicate that Mo, Co, C and N are uniformly distributed over the whole sample. For comparison, the control samples with/without physically mixed Mo source have also been calcinated at the same condition, as denoted Co/Mo–N–C and Co–N–C, respectively, which demonstrate similar morphology as that of Co3Mo3N (Fig. S2). The crystal structure of synthesized Co3Mo3N is further characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD) (Fig. 2 a). The XRD patterns of Co3Mo3N are in line with the cubic phase of Co3Mo3N (JCPDS 89-7953), with the most prominent peak at 2θ = 32.5°, 35.5°, 40°, 42.6°, 46.6° and 72.7° corresponding to the (400), (331), (422), (511), (440) and (822) planes of Co3Mo3N, respectively. Meanwhile, the XRD patterns of Co3Mo3N, Co/Mo–N–C and Co–N–C exhibit the sharp peaks at 44.2°, 51.5°, and 75.9° were well consistent with (111), (200), and (220) planes of cubic cobalt (JCPDS 15-0806), respectively, indicating the presence of metallic Co in all the samples. In addition, inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis shows that the Co/Mo atomic ratio in Co3Mo3N is 10.01 (Table S1) , indicating the existence of metallic Co. Note that the content of nitride can be changed by reasonably varying the feeding ratio of Co/Mo (Fig. S4). The small bulge at about 26° arises from the (002) plane of the graphite carbon, which is in good agreement with the HRTEM results [41]. The carbon structures of the investigated samples are also studied by Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 2b). The obviously lower intensity ratio of D feature to G feature of Co3Mo3N suggests a higher ordering of carbon structure, which should be beneficial for the electron conductivity [42]. It has been demonstrated that transition metal nitrides possess Pt-like catalytic properties, which can be used as active catalytic sites to enhance the degree of graphitization of carbon materials [34]. In addition, one additional strong vibration peak centered at 670 cm−1 can be discerned for Co3Mo3N, which is indexed to the Co–N–Mo [43], suggesting that Co3Mo3N is successful fabricated by one-step method. Moreover, Fig. 2(c) and S5 exhibit the nitrogen absorption/desorption isotherm and the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) pore size distribution of as-fabricated samples. Co3Mo3N possesses a surface area of 204.6 m2 g−1 based on the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) result, which is slightly smaller than that Co/Mo–N–C and Co–N–C (Fig. S5). The N2 hysteresis loop of Co3Mo3N shows a typical type-IV isotherm, indicating the existence of a substantial amount of mesoporous. Co3Mo3N shows obvious mesoporous feature with pore size mainly centered at 3.5 and 7.7 nm, which is conducive to accommodate sulfur and withstand its volume expansion upon charge–discharge process. XPS measurement is also employed to detect the electronic structure of as-synthesized materials. Fig. 2(d–f) shows the XPS spectra of Co 2p, Mo 3d, and N 1s of Co3Mo3N, Co/Mo-N-C, and Co-N-C, respectively. The Co 2p 3/2 spectra can be deconvoluted into four peaks located at 778.7, 780.1, 781.2 and 782.8 eV, which are assigned to metallic cobalt, Co3+, Co2+, and Co–N x , respectively [44]. It's worth noting that due to electron redistribution in Co3Mo3N, the peak positions of Co3+, Co2+, and Co–N x in Co3Mo3N show an apparent upshifts compared with that of Co–N–C and Co/Mo–N–C [45]. This is because the electronegativity of Mo is greater than that of Co, which makes Mo attracts electrons from Co and reduces the electron density around Co. In contrast, the Mo 3d spectrum of Co3Mo3N can be deconvolved into Mo δ + (0 < δ < 4), Mo4+, Mo5+ and Mo6+ species, which are located at 232.2, 233.8, 235.2 and 235.9 eV, respectively [46]. The presence of Mo4+ and Mo6+ species is ascribed to the slight oxidization of sample surface [47], while the Mo δ + species are attributed to Mo–N [48]. In addition, the higher binding energy of Mo 3d peaks compared to that of Co/Mo–N–C is related to the different electronegativities of Mo in Co3Mo3N and Co/Mo–N–C. In contrast, the N 1s peaks of Co3Mo3N all downshift to lower binding energies due to the electron transfer from both Co and Mo atoms to N atoms [49]. Overall, the XPS results imply that the incorporation of Mo decreases/increases the electron density around Co/N [4]. Such electronic structure modulation should be beneficial for the adsorption and conversion of polysulfides by Co3Mo3N, as discussed below. After S infiltration, the obtained S@Co3Mo3N maintains morphology and microstructure without aggregation of sulfur particles as a consequence of the hierarchical porous structure of Co3Mo3N (Figs. S6 and S7). The sulfur content of S@Co3Mo3N is 63.5 wt% as determined by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) under nitrogen atmosphere (Fig. S8). The weight loss of S@Co3Mo3N caused by evaporation of sulfur appear at the higher temperature is lower than that of S@Co–N–C and S@Co/Mo–N–C, which is attributed to the strong affinity towards sulfur for the former [50]. For the catalytic conversion of polysulfides, adsorption is the first step. Therefore, Ultraviolet–visible spectroscopy (UV–vis) and XPS were implemented to clarify the chemical interaction between polysulfides and Co3Mo3N. The static visual adsorption test was implemented to examine the adsorption ability of Co3Mo3N (Fig. 3 a). The color of polysulfide solution with Co3Mo3N is almost transparent after adsorption, while the solutions with Co/Mo–N–C and Co–N–C are still yellow. In addition, the reduced intensity of the characteristic absorption peaks of S6 2− located at ~260 nm and ~280 nm in the UV–vis spectra also suggest the strong chemisorption of polysulfides by Co3Mo3N [51]. To further understand the adsorption mechanism, XPS measurements were conducted. For the Co 2p 3/2 XPS spectra (Fig. 3b), the features appear at 780.1 eV (Co3+), 781.2 eV (Co2+), and 782.8 eV (Co–N x ) without Li2S6 all shift to higher binding energies at 780.2, 781.5, and 783.2 eV, indicating the electrons transfer from Co to Li2S6 [52]. Similar phenomenon is also observed for the Mo 3d XPS spectra (Fig. 3c), with the peaks shifting to the higher binding energies after interacting with Li2S6. Note that the new peak at 230.5 eV is related to the newly formed Mo–S bond [53]. For the S 2p XPS spectrum (Fig. 3d), in addition to the pair of overlapping peaks at 163.5 and 164.2 eV, which correspond to terminal sulfur (ST −1) and bridging sulfur (SB −1) species, a new peak appears at 162.5 eV after interacting with Co3Mo3N, giving evidence of the formation of sulfur–metal bond [54]. It is worth mentioning that the broad features at higher binding energies are related to sulfate [55]. These XPS results clearly demonstrate the strong capture strength of Co3Mo3N to polysulfides. To further elucidate the electrocatalytic effect of Co3Mo3N, CV measurements of Li-S batteries assembled with S@Co–N–C, S@Co/Mo–N–C, and S@Co3Mo3N at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1 were performed. As shown in Fig. 4 (a), the corresponding CV curves show two cathodic peaks (C1 and C2) and one anodic peak (A). In the cathodic scan, the C1 and C2 peaks correspond to the conversion from S8 to long-chain polysulfides (Li2S x , 4 ≤ x ≤ 8) and from long-chain polysulfides (Li2S x , 4 ≤ x ≤ 8) to lithium sulfide (Li2S2/Li2S), respectively [56]. During the subsequent anodic scan, the anodic peak A is regarded as the reversible transformation from Li2S2/Li2S to polysulfides and eventually to sulfur [57]. As expected, the S@Co3Mo3N cathode has the smallest potential difference of peak C2 and peak A (0.43 V) among the three cathodes, indicating that S@Co3Mo3N cathode is more conducive to enhance the polysulfide redox conversion. Fig. 4(b) exhibits the typical CV curves of Li-S batteries with S@Co3Mo3N cathode for the initial four cycles at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1. After activation at the first cycle, the positions of cathodic and anodic peaks are almost overlapped in the following cycles, suggesting highly reversible electrochemical performance of S@Co3Mo3N [58]. To deeply investigate the effect of Co3Mo3N for redox kinetics of polysulfides, CV tests were conducted for Li2S6 symmetric cells assembled with different electrodes at a scan rate of 0.8 mV s−1 in the voltage range of –1 to 1 V (Fig. 4c). It is clearly shown that the Co3Mo3N electrode exhibits the highest redox current accompanied with two symmetric redox couple, indicating the superior catalytic reaction kinetics for polysulfides [59]. Ion diffusion is another vital factor affecting the polysulfide conversion kinetics, which is further investigated by electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS). As shown in Fig. 4(d), the S@Co3Mo3N cathode exhibits the smallest charge-transfer resistance compared with the other two, which also contributes to the fast conversion of polysulfides [60]. It should be noted that the CNTs and metallic cobalt particles present in the synthesized Co3Mo3N also have excellent electrical conductivity, which could contribute to improved charge transfer rate. The Warburg factor (σ) was calculated according to the Nyquist plots (Fig. 4e), which increases in the order of S@Co3Mo3N < S@Co–N–C < S@Co/Mo–N–C, suggesting that Co3Mo3N has the largest Li+ diffusion coefficient (D Li+) [3]. The D Li+ was further calculated according to the Randles-Sevcik Eq. (1), as shown below [61]: (1) I P = 2.69 × 10 5 n 3 / 2 A C 0 D 1 / 2 ν 1 / 2 , where I P indicates the peak current; C 0 is the concentration of Li+ in the electrolyte; A is the area of the active electrode; n represents the charge transfer number; v is the scan rate, and D is the diffusion coefficient of Li + [60]. Fig. 4(j–l) shows the linear fitting results of the peak currents of C1, C2, and A as a function of the square root of the scan rates (v 1/2), respectively, which are proportional to the Li+ diffusion coefficients. The corresponding slope values of the linear fitting results are shown in Fig. 4(f). It is clear that the slope increases in the order of Co–N–C < Co/Mo–N–C < Co3Mo3N for peaks C1 and C2. The slope of peak A is slightly different, with increase in the order of Co/Mo–N–C < Co3Mo3N < Co–N–C. Besides, the calculated D Li+ values as shown in Table S3 accordingly. The above experimental results clearly suggest that Co3Mo3N can effectively entrap and catalytically convert polysulfides to improve the redox kinetics, which should improve the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries. Therefore, the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries assembled with S@Co3Mo3N cathode was investigated. Fig. 5 (a) shows the initial discharge/charge voltage profiles of the Li-S batteries using three different sulfur host materials at 0.5 C (1 C = 1675 mAh g−1). The upper discharge plateau (Q H) is attributed to the reduction of S8 to soluble high-order polysulfides while the lower one (Q L) is ascribed to the further reduction of high-order polysulfides to insoluble Li2S2/Li2S, which is reversibly oxidized to sulfur with a plateau of ~2.3 V in the following charge profile [62]. The voltage hysteresis (ΔV) of S@Co3Mo3N (0.21 V) is much lower than that of S@Co-N-C (0.3 V) and S@Co/Mo-N-C (0.34 V), suggesting that Co3Mo3N facilitates the nucleation and deposition of Li2S [22]. The excellent cycling stability of S@Co3Mo3N cathode is verified at 0.5 C rate, as shown in Fig. 5(b). It should be noted that the initial four cycles are the activation process at 0.1 C [60]. The S@Co3Mo3N cathode delivers a high initial discharge capacity of 1041.1 mAh g−1 with a 77.1% capacity retention after 100 cycles. In contrast, the S@Co-N-C and S@Co/Mo-N-C cathodes present much lower initial capacity and faster capacity decay. These results clearly corroborate that Co3Mo3N can effectively inhibit the polysulfide shuttle effect due to the catalytic effect of Co3Mo3N as discussed above. The enhanced polysulfide redox is also approved by the excellent rate performance. Fig. 5(c) shows the rate performance of S@Co3Mo3N, S@Co–N–C, and S@Co/Mo–N–C cathodes at different current rates from 0.2 C to 3 C. The S@Co3Mo3N cathode exhibits high discharge capacities of 1102.1, 878.1, 784.6, 724.4, and 704.7 mAh g−1 at 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, and 3 C rate, which exceed those of S@Co-N-C and S@Co/Mo-N-C cathodes. When the current density is reduced back to 0.2 C, a discharge capacity of 900.4 mAh g−1 can be achieved, indicating the highly reversible electrochemical performance and stable structure of S@Co3Mo3N cathode. Figs. 5(d) and S9 show the charge/discharge voltage profiles of three cathodes at different rates and the corresponding discharge capacities of high and low discharge voltage plateaus (Q H and Q L), respectively [63]. The voltage profiles of S@Co3Mo3N cathode show a small potential gap at 0.2 C and a multistep discharge profile even at high current rate of 3 C. In comparison, the other electrodes present larger potential gaps at different rates (Fig. S9). In addition, the fast solid-to-liquid transformation in Q H determines the capacity retention and cathode stability due to the polysulfide diffusion and migration, while Q L involves the slow liquid-to-solid conversion from soluble polysulfides to insoluble species [62]. The capacity ratio of Q L to Q H (Q L/Q H) is a good indicator to evaluate the Li+/e− transport within the host materials. As shown in Fig. 5(e) and Table S4, Q L/Q H and Q L of S@Co3Mo3N cathode exhibit the largest values compared with the other two at different rates, implying the adsorbed polysulfides by Co3Mo3N can be sufficiently converted to Li2S2/Li2S. The results demonstrate that Co3Mo3N can effectively adsorb polysulfides and catalyze the transformation of polysulfides into the end-discharge products, thereby enhancing reaction kinetics of polysulfides conversion upon cycling [63,64]. The long-term cycling stability of S@Co3Mo3N cathode was measured at a high current rate 1 C. As illustrated in Fig. 5(g), a high reversible capacity of 444.7 mAh g−1 is maintained over 600 cycles with a prominent capacity retention of 51.5%, corresponding to a low capacity decay rate of 0.08% per cycle. In addition, a high Coulombic efficiency over 99% is obtained after 600 cycles, indicating the superior reversibility of the polysulfide redox reaction. It is worth mentioning that the cycling stability could be further improved by increasing the proportion of Co3Mo3N in the synthesized material, which is still challenging at the moment. To demonstrate the practical application of Co3Mo3N for achieving high areal capacity and energy density, the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries with a higher sulfur loading with the assistance of Co3Mo3N is also evaluated at 0.1 C (Fig. 5f). With a high sulfur loading of 4.8 mg cm−2, the S@Co3Mo3N cathode delivers a high areal capacity of 3.8 mAh cm−2 with a slow capacity decay rate of 0.065% per cycle over 120 cycles (92.5% capacity retention rate). By further increasing the sulfur loading to 5.4 mg cm−2, a high areal capacity of 4.50 mAh cm−2 can be obtained, which is retained at 3.64 mAh cm−2 after 120 cycles. The excellent cycling stability and high areal capacity at high sulfur loading condition are ascribed to the fast polysulfide redox reaction enabled by the catalytic effect of Co3Mo3N, which enables the high sulfur utilization and reduced shuttle effect. In order to further investigate the reaction mechanism, XPS analysis was performed at the different states of charge during the first cycle (Fig. 6 ). The S 2p XPS spectrum of S@Co3Mo3N displays the original peaks of S8 at 164.3 eV (S 2p 3/2) and 165.5 eV (S 2p 1/2) [65]. The located at 162.4 eV is attributed to S – metal bond [66], which originates from the strong interaction between sulfur and Co3Mo3N. After discharging to 2.2 V, the S8 is converted to polysulfides, as evidenced by the appearance of ST −1and SB −1 species from Li2S x . In addition, the strength of S – metal bond is enhanced due to the strong interaction between Li2S x and Co3Mo3N surface. At full-discharge to 1.7 V, the representative peaks of polysulfides disappears, and two new peaks emerge at 162.8 and 161.6 eV, which are attributed to the Li2S2 and Li2S [67]. In the subsequent charge to 2.35 V, the characteristic peaks of polysulfides reappear accompanied with the S – metal bond. After fully charging back to 2.8 V, the spectral shape becomes similar to that of pristine sulfur, suggesting the full conversion from Li2S2/Li2S to sulfur with the assistance of Co3Mo3N. Moreover, the Co 2p 3/2 peaks (Fig. 6b) shift to higher binding energies upon discharge process and to lower binding energies upon charge process, proving the strong interaction between the exposed Co active sites and electronegative polysulfide ligands during cycling [68]. Similar phenomenon is also observed for Mo 3d peaks (Fig. 6c). Note that Mo–S bonds are formed because of the strong interaction between Mo and polysulfides. However, the Mo–S bonds disappear after discharging to 1.7 V, may be caused by the covered Co3Mo3N surface by discharge product Li2S2/Li2S. The above XPS results indicate that the electrons transfer from the Co3Mo3N surface (mainly Co and Mo) to polysulfides through the chemical interaction between metal atoms and sulfur. As sulfur host materials, Co3Mo3N can effectively anchor the sulfur species and enable the high-reversibility transformation between sulfur and Li2S2/Li2S as a consequence of catalytic effect. It should be mentioned that a recent report proposed that single-crystalline Co4N and some other Co-based compounds transformed to polycrystalline CoS x as a consequence of the exothermic reaction between Co atoms and polysulfide [69]. Based on our present experimental results, it is still unclear if such phase transformation occurs for Co3Mo3N in our case, which is out of the scope of our present study and will be studied in our future investigation. To identify the valance and chemical coordination environment change of Co3Mo3N during cycling, Co and Mo K-edge X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectra were further carried out. For the Co K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectrum of Co3Mo3N (Fig. 7 a), the intensity of white-line peak is higher than that of Co foil, suggesting the higher oxidation state. Meanwhile, the pre-edge peak at 7712 eV arises from the Co 1s to 4d transition, which is dipole forbidden for absorbers in a centrosymmetric environment. The existence of this pre-edge feature for Co3Mo3N may imply that the octahedral symmetry of Co atoms in the original Co3Mo3N is slightly distorted, which is different from that of Co foil. The Fourier-transformed (FT) Co K-edge extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectrum of Co3Mo3N (Fig. 7b) is dominated by an obvious FT peak located at 2.1 Å, which is mainly assigned to Co-Co/Mo coordination [70]. In addition, the presence of Co nanoparticles in the synthesized materials also contributes this coordination, which suppresses the Co–N coordination at 1.7 Å. Meanwhile, the valence state and coordination structure of Co3Mo3N almost remain the same after 5 cycles, indicating its structural stability as sulfur host materials in the cycling process. Wavelet transform (WT) is regarded as a good supplement for FT, which can provide the powerful resolution in both k and R spaces [71]. Fig. 7(c–f) shows the Co K-edge WT-EXAFS of the investigated samples. The Co foil shows only one WT maximum at ~7.8 Å−1, which can be ascribed to Co–Co coordination [72]. The Co3Mo3N before and after cycling shows one WT maximum at ~8.0 Å−1, corresponding Co–Co/Mo contribution, which is almost unchanged after 5 cycles, in good agreement with the FT results. Similar to the Co K-edge results, the white-line peak intensity of Mo K-edge for Co3Mo3N is also higher than that of Mo foil (Fig. 7g). Meanwhile, FT-EXAFS results of Co3Mo3N show one strong FT peak located at ~2.5 Å and the other one located at ~1.7 Å, which are assigned to Mo–Mo/Co and Mo–N coordinations, respectively (Fig. 7h). Similar to the results of Co FT-EXAFS, the valence state and coordination structure of Mo also almost remain the same after 5 cycles. Correspondingly, Fig. 7(i–l) also shows the Mo K-edge WT-EXAFS of the investigated samples. The WT-EXAFS results of Mo foil display one WT maximum at ~8.2 Å−1, which is assigned to Mo-Mo coordination. However, FT-EXAFS results of Co3Mo3N cathode show two WT maximum: the one at ~8.8 Å−1 is derived from Mo–Mo/Co, and the other one at ~4.2 Å−1 belongs to Mo–N bonding [73]. These results suggest the good electronic and structural stability of Co3Mo3N over cycling, which makes it a good choice as sulfur host material for Li-S batteries. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, we have successfully designed and synthesized sea urchin-like Co3Mo3N without additional nitrogen source by one-step method, which is utilized as a sulfur host material for Li-S batteries for the first time. It is clearly demonstrated that Co3Mo3N can both effectively anchor and catalyze the conversion of polysulfides to accelerate the electrochemical redox process, thereby inhibiting the polysulfide shuttling. Because of these advantages, the S@Co3Mo3N cathode delivers an excellent rate performance, with a discharge capacity of 704.7 mAh g−1 at 3 C, and a remarkable cycling stability with a capacity fading rate is only 0.08% per cycle over 600 cycles at 1 C. Even at a high sulfur loading of 5.4 mg cm−2, it delivers a high initial areal capacity of 4.50 mAh cm−2, which is stilled retained at 3.64 mAh cm−2 after 120 cycles. Furthermore, the catalytic mechanism and structural stability of Co3Mo3N during cycling were elucidated by a combination of XPS and XAFS. This work inaugurates a new strategy of structure-catalysis engineering of bimetallic nitride and sheds light on the catalytic mechanism of polysulfide conversion, which is expected to promote the application of bimetallic nitride as host materials for Li-S batteries. coredata.dc:description: Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries are considered as one of the most promising next generation energy storage systems due to the high theoretical specific capacity, low cost, and environmental benignity. However, the notorious shuttle effect of polysulfides hinders the practical application of Li-S batteries. Herein, we have rationally designed and synthesized sea urchin-like Co-Mo bimetallic nitride (Co3Mo3N) in the absence of additional nitrogen sources with only one step, which was applied as the sulfur host materials for Li-S batteries. The results indicate that Co3Mo3N can efficiently anchor and catalyze the conversion of polysulfides, thus accelerating the electrochemical reaction kinetics and enabling prominent electrochemical properties. As a consequence, the S@Co3Mo3N cathode exhibits a high rate performance of 705 mAh g−1 at 3 C rate and an excellent cycling stability with a low capacity fading rate of 0.08% per cycle at 1 C over 600 cycles. Even at a high sulfur loading of 5.4 cmg cm−2, it delivers a high initial areal capacity of 4.50 mAh cm−2, which is still retained at 3.64 mAh cm−2 after 120 cycles. Furthermore, the catalytic mechanism and structural stability of Co3Mo3N during cycling were elucidated by a combination of X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and X-ray absorption fine structure. This work highlights the strategy of structure-catalysis engineering of bimetallic nitride, which is expected to have a wide application in Li-S batteries.
